video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, followed by a disclaimer slide stating that the video is for educational purposes only and not for commercial use. It mentions that the video is under the Creative Commons Attribution license and must be attributed to 'Labs for Life, a partnership project of MOHFW and CDC.' Acknowledgments are given to various medical associations and colleges. The next slide introduces the 'ESR Westergren Method Learning Objectives,' outlining the video's aim to educate viewers on the determination of Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate by the Westergren method, including test procedure and result interpretation. The video then transitions to a slide titled 'ESR by Westergren Method,' explaining that ESR measures the distance red blood cells (RBC) will fall along the length of a tube over a given time period. It is described as a non-specific test useful for monitoring chronic disorders like Rheumatoid Arthritis, Tuberculosis, and Multiple Myeloma. The slide includes an image of a blood sedimentation tube and a digital timer set to zero, placed on a white surface with a rack labeled with numbers 1 to 4. The video maintains a consistent educational tone throughout, focusing on the ESR Westergren method and its applications.

The video begins with a title slide displaying "ESR by Westergren Method" in bold yellow text against a dark green background, accompanied by two green diagonal stripes on either side. The scene transitions to a close-up of a gloved hand holding a test tube filled with a red liquid, presumably blood, against a backdrop of a grey curtain. The text "Rate of fall of RBCs in diluted plasma" appears in a black box with a white arrow pointing to the test tube, explaining the principle behind the Westergren method for measuring erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The video then lists factors affecting ESR, starting with "Depends upon" followed by "Difference in specific gravity between RBC and plasma" and "Extent to which the RBC form rouleaux," each point marked with a bullet point. The background remains consistent with the dark green color and the test tube image. The next slide introduces "Factors affecting ESR" in a black box with a white arrow, listing "Ratio of red cells to plasma" and "Plasma viscosity, which depends upon plasma protein levels like fibrinogen, globulin etc." The video maintains a consistent visual theme throughout, focusing on the educational content related to the Westergren method for ESR measurement.

The video begins with a close-up of a white plastic rack labeled "U-Tek" with numbered slots from 1 to 12, designed for holding test tubes. The scene transitions to a gloved hand holding a clear plastic test tube, highlighting its open end and measurement markings. The focus then shifts to a detailed view of the test tube's measurement markings, emphasizing the precision required for the procedure. The video then presents a slide titled "ESR by Westergren Method," detailing the equipment and reagents needed, including disposable tubes and ESR vacutainers with black tops containing 3.8% Na Citrate. The slide also mentions the use of EDTA tubes as an alternative, with specific instructions on mixing 1 volume of 3.8% Sodium Citrate Solution with 4 volumes of blood. The final frames show a gloved hand holding an EDTA tube, reinforcing the procedural steps and the importance of proper equipment and reagents in the ESR by Westergren Method. The background remains consistent with a dark, clinical setting, emphasizing the laboratory environment.

The video begins with a title slide displaying the text "ESR by Westergren Method" at the top and "Preparation of 3.8% Sodium Citrate Solution" in the center, set against a dark green background with a subtle gradient. The title is highlighted with a teal banner and yellow accents. The next frame provides detailed instructions for preparing the solution, listing "3.8 gms of anhydrous Sodium Citrate + distilled water" and "Total volume upto 100ml" in bullet points, maintaining the same background and title format. The video then transitions to a single instruction, "Keep the solution in the refrigerator," presented in a bullet point format, with the same title and background. The final frame reiterates the instruction to keep the solution in the refrigerator, with no additional text or visual changes. The video maintains a consistent dark green background throughout, with a focus on the instructional text related to the Westergren method for ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) testing.

The video presents a series of instructional slides on the "ESR by Westergren Method," focusing on precautions to be taken during the procedure. The background is a dark green gradient, with the title "ESR by Westergren Method" prominently displayed at the top in a yellow banner with blue text. The word "Precautions" is highlighted in blue below the title. The first slide emphasizes the importance of using the correct type and proportion of anticoagulant. Subsequent slides add more precautions, such as performing the test on non-hemolyzed samples, using disposal sedimentation tubes, keeping the tubes upright, ensuring no air bubbles while filling the tube, and avoiding heat sources or direct sunlight. The final slide advises keeping the tubes away from vibrations, like those from a centrifuge. Each precaution is listed in a bullet-point format with a small orange circle preceding the text. The video maintains a consistent visual style throughout, with no people or environmental details visible, focusing solely on the instructional content.
